<br>
<div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Our construction commitments include funds owed to third parties for projects currently under construction. These amounts are reflected in other current liabilities in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Our purchase obligations include commitments to be utilized in the normal course of business, such as several contracts to purchase raw materials utilized in our manufacturing plants and several contracts to purchase energy to be used in our stores and manufacturing facilities. Our obligations also include management fees for facilities operated by third parties. Any upfront vendor allowances or incentives associated with outstanding purchase commitments are recorded as either current or long-term liabilities in our Consolidated Balance Sheets.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-23</font></font></div>
</div>

<br>
<hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
<div id="PGBRK">
<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">&#160;</div>
</div>

<br>
<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
<div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">As of January 29, 2011, we maintained a $2 billion, unsecured revolving credit facility that, unless extended, terminates on May 15, 2014. Outstanding borrowings under the credit agreement and commercial paper borrowings, and some outstanding letters of credit, reduce funds available under the credit agreement. In addition to the credit agreement, we maintained three uncommitted money market lines totaling $100 million in the aggregate. The money market lines allow us to borrow from banks at mutually agreed upon rates, usually at rates below the rates offered under the credit agreement. As of January 29, 2011, we had no borrowings under our credit agreement, money market lines or outstanding commercial paper. The outstanding letters of credit that reduce funds available under our credit agreement totaled $134 million as of January 29, 2011.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>In addition to the available credit mentioned above, as of January 29, 2011, we had authorized for issuance $2 billion of securities under a shelf registration statement filed with the SEC and effective on December 15, 2010.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>We also maintain surety bonds related primarily to our self-insured workers compensation claims. These bonds are required by most states in which we are self-insured for workers&#8217; compensation and are placed with third-party insurance providers to insure payment of our obligations in the event we are unable to meet our claim payment obligations up to our self-insured retention levels. These bonds do not represent liabilities of Kroger, as we already have reserves on our books for the claims costs. Market changes may make the surety bonds more costly and, in some instances, availability of these bonds may become more limited, which could affect our costs of, or access to, such bonds. Although we do not believe increased costs or decreased availability would significantly affect our ability to access these surety bonds, if this does become an issue, we would issue letters of credit, in states where allowed, against our credit facility to meet the state bonding requirements. This could increase our cost and decrease the funds available under our credit facility.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>We have guaranteed half of the indebtedness of two real estate entities in which we have a 50% ownership interest. Our share of the responsibility for this indebtedness, should the entities be unable to meet their obligations, totals approximately $7 million. Based on the covenants underlying this indebtedness as of January 29, 2011, we believe that it is unlikely that we will be responsible for repayment of these obligations.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>We also are contingently liable for leases that have been assigned to various third parties in connection with facility closings and dispositions. We could be required to satisfy obligations under the leases if any of the assignees are unable to fulfill their lease obligations. Due to the wide distribution of our assignments among third parties, and various other remedies available to us, we believe the likelihood that we will be required to assume a material amount of these obligations is remote. We have agreed to indemnify certain third-party logistics operators for certain expenses, including pension trust fund contribution obligations and withdrawal liabilities.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>In addition to the above, we enter into various indemnification agreements and take on indemnification obligations in the ordinary course of business. Such arrangements include indemnities against third party claims arising out of agreements to provide services to Kroger; indemnities related to the sale of our securities; indemnities of directors, officers and employees in connection with the performance of their work; and indemnities of individuals serving as fiduciaries on benefit plans. While Kroger&#8217;s aggregate indemnification obligation could result in a material liability, we are not aware of any current matter that could result in a material liability.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-24</font></font></div>
</div>

<br>
<hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
<div id="PGBRK">
<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">&#160;</div>
</div>

<br>
<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
<div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">R</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">ECENTLY</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> A</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">DOPTED</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> A</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">CCOUNTING</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> S</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">TANDARDS</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In January 2010, the FASB amended its standards related to fair value measurements and disclosures, which were effective for interim and annual fiscal periods beginning after December 15, 2009, except for disclosures about certain Level 3 activity that will become effective for interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2010. The new standards require us to disclose transfers in and out of Level 1 and Level 2 fair value measurements and describe the reasons for the transfers as well as activity in Level 3 fair value measurements. The new standards also require a more detailed level of disaggregation of the assets and liabilities being measured as well as increased disclosures regarding inputs and valuation techniques of the fair value measurements. We adopted the amended standards effective January 31, 2010, except for disclosures about certain Level 3 activity, which will be effective starting January 30, 2011. See Note 7 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for our fair value measurements and disclosures.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>In June 2009, the FASB amended its existing standards related to the consolidation of VIEs, which was effective for interim and annual fiscal periods beginning after November 15, 2009. The new standards require an entity to analyze whether its variable interests give it a controlling financial interest of a VIE and outlines what defines a primary beneficiary. The new standards amend GAAP by: (a) changing certain rules for determining whether an entity is a VIE; (b) replacing the quantitative approach previously required for determining the primary beneficiary with a more qualitative approach; and (c) requiring entities to continuously analyze whether they are the primary beneficiary of a VIE, among other amendments. The new standards also require enhanced disclosures regarding an entity&#8217;s involvement in a VIE. We adopted the amended standards effective January 31, 2010. The adoption of these new standards did not have a material effect on our Consolidated Financial Statements.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Effective February 1, 2009, we adopted the new standards that clarify that share-based payment awards that entitle their holders to receive nonforfeitable dividends before vesting should be considered participating securities and included in the computation of EPS pursuant to the two-class method. See Note 9 to the Consolidated Financial Statements for further discussion of its adoption.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">O</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">UTLOOK</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>This discussion and analysis contains certain forward-looking statements about Kroger&#8217;s future performance. These statements are based on management&#8217;s assumptions and beliefs in light of the information currently available. Such statements relate to, among other things: projected changes in net earnings attributable to The Kroger Co.; identical supermarket sales growth; expected product cost; expected pension plan contributions; our ability to generate operating cash flow; projected capital expenditures; square footage growth; opportunities to reduce costs; cash flow requirements; and our operating plan for the future; and are indicated by words such as &#8220;comfortable,&#8221; &#8220;committed,&#8221; &#8220;will,&#8221; &#8220;expect,&#8221; &#8220;goal,&#8221; &#8220;should,&#8221; &#8220;intend,&#8221; &#8220;target,&#8221; &#8220;believe,&#8221; &#8220;anticipate,&#8221; &#8220;plan,&#8221; and similar words or phrases. These forward-looking statements are subject to uncertainties and other factors that could cause actual results to differ materially.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Statements elsewhere in this report and below regarding our expectations, projections, beliefs, intentions or strategies are forward-looking statements within the meaning of Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. While we believe that the statements are accurate, uncertainties about the general economy, our labor relations, our ability to execute our plans on a timely basis and other uncertainties described below could cause actual results to differ materially.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-25</font></font></div>
</div>

<br>
<hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
<div id="PGBRK">
<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">&#160;</div>
</div>

<br>
<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
<ul style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We expect net earnings per diluted share in the range of $1.80-$1.92 for 2011. We expect the second</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">and third quarter earnings per diluted share growth rate to be below the annual growth rate due to</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">tax benefits recognized in 2010. The growth in the second quarter is expected to be the lowest of the</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">year.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We expect identical supermarket sales growth, excluding fuel sales, of 3.0%-4.0% in 2011.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">For 2011, we will continue to focus on improving sales growth, in accordance with our Customer 1<font style="FONT-SIZE: 70%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: text-top">st</font> strategy, by making investments in gross margin and customer shopping experiences. We expect to finance these investments primarily with operating cost reductions. We expect non-fuel operating margins for 2011 to be comparable to 2010, excluding the non-cash goodwill impairment charge.</font><br>
&#160; </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">For 2011, we expect fuel margins, which can be highly volatile, to be approximately $0.115 per gallon,</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">and we expect continued strong growth in fuel gallons sold.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">For 2011, we expect our annualized LIFO charge to be approximately $50 million to $75 million. This</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">forecast is based on estimated cost changes for products in our inventory.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">For 2011, we expect interest expense to be approximately $460 million.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We plan to use cash flow primarily for capital investments, to maintain our current debt coverage</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">ratios, to pay cash dividends, and to repurchase stock. As market conditions change, we re-evaluate</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">these uses of cash flow.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We expect to obtain sales growth from new square footage, as well as from increased productivity</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">from existing locations.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Capital expenditures reflect our strategy of growth through expansion, as well as focusing on</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">productivity increases from our existing store base through remodels. In addition, we will continue our</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">emphasis on self-development and ownership of real estate, logistics and technology improvements. </font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The continued capital spending in technology is focused on improving store operations, logistics,</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">manufacturing procurement, category management, merchandising and buying practices, and should</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">reduce merchandising costs. We intend to continue using cash flow from operations to finance capital</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">expenditure requirements. We expect capital investments for 2011 to be in the range of $1.7-$1.9</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">billion, excluding acquisitions and purchases of leased facilities. We expect total food store square</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">footage to grow approximately 1.0%-1.5% before acquisitions and operational closings.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Based on current operating trends, we believe that cash flow from operations and other sources of</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">liquidity, including borrowings under our commercial paper program and bank credit facility, will be</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">adequate to meet anticipated requirements for working capital, capital expenditures, interest payments</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">and scheduled principal payments for the foreseeable future. We also believe we have adequate</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">coverage of our debt covenants to continue to respond effectively to competitive conditions.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We believe we have adequate sources of cash, if needed, under our credit facility and other borrowing</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">sources.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We expect that our OG&amp;A results will be affected by increased costs, such as higher employee benefit</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">costs and credit card fees, offset by improved productivity from process changes and leverage gained</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">through sales increases.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We expect that our effective tax rate for 2011 will be approximately 36.0%, excluding the resolution</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">of any tax issues.</font> </li>
</ul>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-26</font></font></div>
</div>

<br>
<hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
<div id="PGBRK">
<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">&#160;</div>
</div>

<br>
<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
<ul style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We expect rent expense, as a percentage of total sales and excluding closed-store activity, will decrease</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">due to the emphasis our current strategy places on ownership of real estate.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We believe that in 2011 there will be opportunities to reduce our operating costs in such areas as</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">administration, productivity improvements, shrink, warehousing and transportation. We intend to</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">invest most of these savings in our core business to drive profitable sales growth and offer improved</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">value and shopping experiences for our customers.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We do not expect to make a cash contribution to the Company-sponsored defined benefit pension</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">plans during 2011. If a contribution is made to the Company-sponsored defined benefit pension plans,</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">we expect any elective contributions made during 2011 will decrease our required contributions in</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">future years. Among other things, investment performance of plan assets, the interest rates required</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">to be used to calculate the pension obligations, and future changes in legislation, will determine the</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">amounts of any additional contributions. We expect 2011 expense for Company-sponsored defined</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">benefit pension plans to be approximately $80 million. In addition, we expect 401(k) Retirement</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Savings Account Plan cash contributions and expense from automatic and matching contributions to</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">participants to increase slightly in 2011, compared to 2010.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We expect to contribute approximately $300 million to multi-employer pension plans in 2011,</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">subject to collective bargaining. In addition, we expect meaningful increases in expense as a result of</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">increases in multi-employer pension plan contributions over the next few years.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We do not anticipate additional goodwill impairments in 2011.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We have various labor agreements that will be negotiated in 2011, covering store employees in southern</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">California, Memphis and West Virginia. We will also negotiate agreements with the Teamsters who</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">represent some of our associates in distribution and manufacturing operation in the Midwest. Upon</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">the expiration of our collective bargaining agreements, work stoppages by the affected workers could</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">occur if we are unable to negotiate new contracts with labor unions. A prolonged work stoppage</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">affecting a substantial number of locations could have a material adverse effect on our results. In</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">all of these contracts, rising health care and pension costs will continue to be an important issue in</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">negotiations.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We expect our business model to produce annual earnings per diluted share growth on average of</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">6.0% to 8.0% over each rolling three to five year time period. Including our dividend, our business</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">model is expected to generate total shareholder return on average of 8.0% to 10.0% over each rolling</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">three to five year time period.<br>
&#160; </font><br>
<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Various uncertainties and other factors could cause us to fail to achieve our goals. These include:<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The extent to which our sources of liquidity are sufficient to meet our requirements may be affected</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">by the state of the financial markets and the effect that such condition has on our ability to issue</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">commercial paper at acceptable rates. Our ability to borrow under our committed lines of credit,</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">including our bank credit facilities, could be impaired if one or more of our lenders under those lines</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">is unwilling or unable to honor its contractual obligation to lend to us.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Changes in market conditions could affect our cash flow.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Our ability to achieve sales and earnings goals may be affected by: labor disputes; industry</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">consolidation; pricing and promotional activities of existing and new competitors, including non-</font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">traditional competitors, and the aggressiveness of that competition; our response to these actions;</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">the state of the economy, including interest rates, the inflationary and deflationary trends in certain</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">commodities, and the unemployment rate; the effect that increased fuel costs have on consumer</font> </li>
</ul>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-27</font></font></div>
</div>

<br>
<hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
<div id="PGBRK">
<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">&#160;</div>
</div>

<br>
<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
<div style="MARGIN-LEFT: 40px" align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">spending; changes in government-funded benefit programs; manufacturing commodity costs; diesel fuel costs related to our logistics operations; trends in consumer spending; the extent to which our customers exercise caution in their purchasing in response to economic conditions; the inconsistent pace of the economic recovery; changes in inflation or deflation in product and operating costs; stock repurchases; and the success of our future growth plans. Our ability to achieve sales and earnings goals may also be affected by our ability to manage the factors identified above.</font></div>

<ul style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The extent to which the adjustments we are making to our strategy create value for our shareholders</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">will depend primarily on the reaction of our customers and our competitors to these adjustments,</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">as well as operating conditions, including inflation or deflation, increased competitive activity, and</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">cautious spending behavior of our customers.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Our product cost inflation could vary from our estimate due to general economic conditions, weather,</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">availability of raw materials and ingredients in the products that we sell and their packaging, and</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">other factors beyond our control.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Our ability to use free cash flow to continue to maintain our debt coverage and to reward our</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">shareholders could be affected by unanticipated increases in net total debt, our inability to generate</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">free cash flow at the levels anticipated, and our failure to generate expected earnings.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The timing of our recognition of LIFO expense will be affected primarily by changes in product costs</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">during the year.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">If actual results differ significantly from anticipated future results for certain reporting units including</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">variable interest entities, an impairment loss for any excess of the carrying value of the reporting</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">units&#8217; goodwill over the implied fair value would have to be recognized.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In addition to the factors identified above, our identical store sales growth could be affected by</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">increases in Kroger private label sales, the effect of our &#8220;sister stores&#8221; (new stores opened in close</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">proximity to an existing store) and reductions in retail pricing.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Our operating margins, without fuel, could decline more than expected if we are unable to pass</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">on any cost increases, fail to deliver the cost savings contemplated or if changes in the cost of our</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">inventory and the timing of those changes differ from our expectations.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We could fail to realize our expected operating margin per gallon of fuel and fuel gallons sold based</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">upon changes in the price of fuel, a change in our operating costs, or if a pattern of rapid changes in</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">fuel costs occurs.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">We have estimated our exposure to the claims and litigation arising in the normal course of business,</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">as well as to the material litigation facing Kroger, and believe we have made provisions where it is</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">reasonably possible to estimate and where an adverse outcome is probable. Unexpected outcomes in</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">these matters, however, could result in an adverse effect on our earnings.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Consolidation in the food industry is likely to continue and the effects on our business, either favorable</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">or unfavorable, cannot be foreseen.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Rent expense, which includes subtenant rental income, could be adversely affected by the state of the</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">economy, increased store closure activity and future consolidation.</font> </li>
</ul>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-28</font></font></div>
</div>

<br>
<hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
<div id="PGBRK">
<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">&#160;</div>
</div>

<br>
<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
<ul style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Depreciation expense, which includes the amortization of assets recorded under capital leases, is</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">computed principally using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of individual</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">assets, or the remaining terms of leases. Use of the straight-line method of depreciation creates a risk</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">that future asset write-offs or potential impairment charges related to store closings would be larger</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">than if an accelerated method of depreciation were followed.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Our effective tax rate may differ from the expected rate due to changes in laws, the status of pending</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">items with various taxing authorities, and the deductibility of certain expenses.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The actual amount of automatic and matching cash contributions to our 401(k) Retirement Savings</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Account Plan will depend on the number of participants, savings rate, plan compensation, and length</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">of service of participants.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Our contributions and recorded expense related to multi-employer pension funds could increase</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">more than anticipated. Should asset values in these funds deteriorate, if employers withdraw from</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">these funds without providing for their share of the liability, or should our estimates prove to be</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">understated, our contributions could increase more rapidly than we have anticipated.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">If volatility in the financial markets continues or worsens, our contributions to Company-sponsored</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">defined benefit pension plans could increase more than anticipated in future years.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Changes in laws or regulations, including changes in accounting standards, taxation requirements</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">and environmental laws may have a material effect on our financial statements.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Changes in the general business and economic conditions in our operating regions may affect the</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">shopping habits of our customers, which could affect sales and earnings.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Changes in our product mix may negatively affect certain financial indicators. For example, we</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">continue to add supermarket fuel centers to our store base. Since gasoline generates low profit margins,</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">we expect to see our FIFO gross profit margins decline as gasoline sales increase. Although this</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">negatively affects our FIFO gross margin, gasoline sales provide a positive effect on OG&amp;A expense</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">as a percentage of sales.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Our capital expenditures, expected square footage growth, and number of store projects completed</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">over the next fiscal year could differ from our estimate if we are unsuccessful in acquiring suitable</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">sites for new stores, if development costs vary from those budgeted, if our logistics and technology</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">or store projects are not completed on budget or within the time frame projected, or if economic</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">conditions fail to improve, or worsen.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Interest expense could be adversely affected by the interest rate environment, changes in our credit</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">ratings, fluctuations in the amount of outstanding debt, decisions to incur prepayment penalties on</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">the early redemption of debt and any factor that adversely affects our operations and results in an</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">increase in debt.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Impairment losses, including goodwill, could be affected by changes in our assumptions of future cash</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">flows, market values or business valuations in the market. Our cash flow projections include several</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">years of projected cash flows which would be affected by changes in the economic environment, real</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">estate market values, competitive activity, inflation and customer behavior.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Our estimated expense and obligation for Kroger-sponsored pension plans and other post-retirement</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">benefits could be affected by changes in the assumptions used in calculating those amounts. These</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">assumptions include, among others, the discount rate, the expected long-term rate of return on plan</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">assets, average life expectancy and the rate of increases in compensation and health care costs.</font> </li>
</ul>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-29</font></font></div>
</div>

<br>
<hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
<div id="PGBRK">
<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">&#160;</div>
</div>

<br>
<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
<ul style="FONT-SIZE: 10pt; TEXT-ALIGN: justify">
<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Adverse weather conditions could increase the cost our suppliers charge for their products, or may</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">decrease customer demand for certain products. Increases in demand for certain commodities</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">could also increase the cost our suppliers charge for their products. Additionally, increases in the</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">cost of inputs, such as utility costs or raw material costs, could negatively affect financial ratios and</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">earnings.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Although we presently operate only in the United States, civil unrest in foreign countries in which</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">our suppliers do business may affect the prices we are charged for imported goods. If we are unable</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">to pass on these increases to our customers, our FIFO gross margin and net earnings would suffer.<br>
&#160;</font> </li>

<li><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Earnings and sales also may be affected by adverse weather conditions, particularly to the extent that</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">hurricanes, tornadoes, floods, earthquakes, and other conditions disrupt our operations or those of</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">our suppliers; create shortages in the availability or increases in the cost of products that we sell in</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">our stores or materials and ingredients we use in our manufacturing facilities; or raise the cost of</font> <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">supplying energy to our various operations.</font> </li>
</ul>

<div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Other factors and assumptions not identified above could also cause actual results to differ materially from those set forth in the forward-looking information. Accordingly, actual events and results may vary significantly from those included in, contemplated or implied by forward-looking statements made by us or our representatives.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-30</font></font></div>
</div>

<br>
<hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
<div id="PGBRK">
<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">&#160;</div>
</div>

<br>
<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
<div style="TEXT-ALIGN: center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">R</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">EPORT</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> </font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">OF</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> I</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">NDEPENDENT</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> R</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">EGISTERED</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> P</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">UBLIC</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> A</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">CCOUNTING</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> F</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">IRM</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">To the Shareowners and Board of Directors of<br>
The Kroger Co.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">In our opinion, the accompanying consolidated balance sheets and the related consolidated statements of operations, cash flows and changes in shareowners&#8217; equity present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of The Kroger Co. and its subsidiaries at January 29, 2011 and January 30, 2010, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three years in the period ended January 29, 2011</font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> </font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America. Also in our opinion, the Company maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of January 29, 2011, based on criteria established in </font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Internal Control - Integrated Framework </font></font><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO). The Company&#8217;s management is responsible for these financial statements, for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in Management&#8217;s Report on Internal Control over Financial Reporting appearing on page A-1. Our responsibility is to express opinions on these financial statements and on the Company&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting based on our integrated audits. We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement and whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects. Our audits of the financial statements included examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall financial statement presentation. Our audit of internal control over financial reporting included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists, and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk. Our audits also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances. We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinions.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>A company&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A company&#8217;s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company&#8217;s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-31</font></font></div>
</div>

<br>
<hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
<div id="PGBRK">
<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">&#160;</div>
</div>

<br>
<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements. Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.</font></div>

Cincinnati, Ohio<br>
March 29, 2011</font></div>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-32</font></font></div>

<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">THE KROGER CO.</font></font></div>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">C</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">ONSOLIDATED</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> B</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">ALANCE</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> S</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">HEETS</font></font></div>

<br>
<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The accompanying notes are an integral part of the consolidated financial statements.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-36</font></font></div>
</div>

<br>
<hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
<div id="PGBRK">
<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">&#160;</div>
</div>

<br>
<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">N</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">OTES</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> </font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">TO</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> C</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">ONSOLIDATED</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> F</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">INANCIAL</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> S</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">TATEMENTS</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">All dollar amounts are in millions except share and per share amounts.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">Certain prior-year amounts have been reclassified to conform to current year presentation.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">1 . A</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">CCOUNTING</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> P</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">OLICIES</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The following is a summary of the significant accounting policies followed in preparing these financial statements.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;<font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic">Description of Business, Basis of Presentation and Principles of Consolidation</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The Kroger Co. (the &#8220;Company&#8221;) was founded in 1883 and incorporated in 1902. As of January 29, 2011, the Company was one of the largest retailers in the United States based on annual sales. The Company also manufactures and processes food for sale by its supermarkets. The accompanying financial statements include the consolidated accounts of the Company, its wholly-owned subsidiaries and the Variable Interest Entities (&#8220;VIE&#8221;) in which the Company is the primary beneficiary. Significant intercompany transactions and balances have been eliminated.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Company reflects certain promotional allowances in its LIFO charge. During the first quarter 2010 LIFO analysis, the Company revised the LIFO reserve to reflect certain prior year promotional allowances in prior year LIFO indices. By not including these promotional allowances in all LIFO indices, the Company overstated its LIFO reserve for years 2007 and prior. The Company believes this correction is not material to any individual year or any quarterly period within the years presented. As a result, the Company has increased beginning accumulated earnings and reduced its LIFO reserve in the Consolidated Financial Statements by $33 ($20 after-tax).</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;</font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic">Fiscal Year</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The Company&#8217;s fiscal year ends on the Saturday nearest January 31. The last three fiscal years consist of the 52-week periods ended January 29, 2011, January 30, 2010 and January 31, 2009.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;</font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic">Pervasiveness of Estimates</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The preparation of financial statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles (&#8220;GAAP&#8221;) requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities. Disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities as of the date of the consolidated financial statements and the reported amounts of consolidated revenues and expenses during the reporting period also is required. Actual results could differ from those estimates.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;</font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic">Cash and temporary cash investments</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Cash and temporary cash investments represent store cash and Euros held to settle Euro-denominated contracts. The Company valued its carrying amount of Euros at the spot rates as of January 29, 2011, January 30, 2010, and January 31, 2009.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;</font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic">Inventories</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Inventories are stated at the lower of cost (principally on a last-in, first-out &#8220;LIFO&#8221; basis) or market. In total, approximately 97% of inventories for 2010 and 2009 were valued using the LIFO method. Cost for the balance of the inventories, including substantially all fuel inventories, was determined using the first-in, </font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-37</font></font></div>
</div>

<br>
<hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
<div id="PGBRK">
<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">&#160;</div>
</div>

<br>
<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">N</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">OTES</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> </font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">TO</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> C</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">ONSOLIDATED</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> F</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">INANCIAL</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> S</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">TATEMENTS</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">, C</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">ONTINUED</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">first-out (&#8220;FIFO&#8221;) method. Replacement cost was higher than the carrying amount by $827 at January 29, 2011 and $770 at January 30, 2010. The Company follows the Link-Chain, Dollar-Value LIFO method for purposes of calculating its LIFO charge or credit.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The item-cost method of accounting to determine inventory cost before the LIFO adjustment is followed for substantially all store inventories at the Company&#8217;s supermarket divisions. This method involves counting each item in inventory, assigning costs to each of these items based on the actual purchase costs (net of vendor allowances and cash discounts) of each item and recording the cost of items sold. The item-cost method of accounting allows for more accurate reporting of periodic inventory balances and enables management to more precisely manage inventory when compared to the retail method of accounting.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The Company evaluates inventory shortages throughout the year based on actual physical counts in its facilities. Allowances for inventory shortages are recorded based on the results of these counts to provide for estimated shortages as of the financial statement date.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;</font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic">Property, Plant and Equipment</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Property, plant and equipment are recorded at cost. Depreciation expense, which includes the amortization of assets recorded under capital leases, is computed principally using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of individual assets. Buildings and land improvements are depreciated based on lives varying from 10 to 40 years. All new purchases of store equipment are assigned lives varying from three to nine years. Leasehold improvements are amortized over the shorter of the lease term to which they relate, which varies from four to 25 years, or the useful life of the asset. Manufacturing plant and distribution center equipment is depreciated over lives varying from three to 15 years. Information technology assets are generally depreciated over five years. Depreciation and amortization expense was $1,600 in 2010, $1,525 in 2009 and $1,443 in 2008.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Interest costs on significant projects constructed for the Company&#8217;s own use are capitalized as part of the costs of the newly constructed facilities. Upon retirement or disposal of assets, the cost and related accumulated depreciation are removed from the balance sheet and any gain or loss is reflected in net earnings.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;</font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic">Deferred Rent</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The Company recognizes rent holidays, including the time period during which the Company has access to the property for construction of buildings or improvements and escalating rent provisions on a straight-line basis over the term of the lease. The deferred amount is included in Other Current Liabilities and Other Long-Term Liabilities on the Company&#8217;s Consolidated Balance Sheets.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;</font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic">Goodwill</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The Company reviews goodwill for impairment during the fourth quarter of each year, and also upon the occurrence of trigger events. The reviews are performed at the operating division level. Generally, fair value is determined using a multiple of earnings, or discounted projected future cash flows, and is compared to the carrying value of a division for purposes of identifying potential impairment. Projected future cash flows are based on management&#8217;s knowledge of the current operating environment and expectations for the future. If potential for impairment is identified, the fair value of a division is measured against the fair value of its underlying assets and liabilities, excluding goodwill, to estimate an implied fair </font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-38</font></font></div>
</div>

<br>
<hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
<div id="PGBRK">
<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">&#160;</div>
</div>

<br>
<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">N</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">OTES</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> </font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">TO</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> C</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">ONSOLIDATED</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> F</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">INANCIAL</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"> S</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">TATEMENTS</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">, C</font></font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font size="1" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">ONTINUED</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">value of the division&#8217;s goodwill. Goodwill impairment is recognized for any excess of the carrying value of the division&#8217;s goodwill over the implied fair value. Results of the goodwill impairment reviews performed during 2010, 2009 and 2008 are summarized in Note 2 to the Consolidated Financial Statements.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;</font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic">Impairment of Long-Lived Assets</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; <font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">The Company monitors the carrying value of long-lived assets for potential impairment each quarter based on whether certain trigger events have occurred. These events include current period losses combined with a history of losses or a projection of continuing losses or a significant decrease in the market value of an asset. When a trigger event occurs, an impairment calculation is performed, comparing projected undiscounted future cash flows, utilizing current cash flow information and expected growth rates related to specific stores, to the carrying value for those stores. If the Company identifies impairment for long-lived assets to be held and used, the Company compares the assets&#8217; current carrying value to the assets&#8217; fair value. Fair value is based on current market values or discounted future cash flows. The Company records impairment when the carrying value exceeds fair market value. With respect to owned property and equipment held for sale, the value of the property and equipment is adjusted to reflect recoverable values based on previous efforts to dispose of similar assets and current economic conditions. Impairment is recognized for the excess of the carrying value over the estimated fair market value, reduced by estimated direct costs of disposal. The Company recorded asset impairments in the normal course of business totaling $25, $48 and $26 in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively. Included in the 2009 amount are asset impairments recorded totaling $24 for a southern California reporting unit. Costs to reduce the carrying value of long-lived assets for each of the years presented have been included in the Consolidated Statements of Operations as &#8220;Operating, general and administrative&#8221; expense.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;</font><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-STYLE: italic">Store Closing Costs</font></font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The Company provides for closed store liabilities relating to the present value of the estimated remaining noncancellable lease payments after the closing date, net of estimated subtenant income. The Company estimates the net lease liabilities using a discount rate to calculate the present value of the remaining net rent payments on closed stores. The closed store lease liabilities usually are paid over the lease terms associated with the closed stores, which generally have remaining terms ranging from one to 20 years. Adjustments to closed store liabilities primarily relate to changes in subtenant income and actual exit costs differing from original estimates. Adjustments are made for changes in estimates in the period in which the change becomes known. Store closing liabilities are reviewed quarterly to ensure that any accrued amount that is not a sufficient estimate of future costs, or that no longer is needed for its originally intended purpose, is adjusted to income in the proper period.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="justify"><font size="2" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman"><font size="3" style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Owned stores held for disposal are reduced to their estimated net realizable value. Costs to reduce the carrying values of property, equipment and leasehold improvements are accounted for in accordance with the Company&#8217;s policy on impairment of long-lived assets. Inventory write-downs, if any, in connection with store closings, are classified in &#8220;Merchandise costs.&#8221; Costs to transfer inventory and equipment from closed stores are expensed as incurred.</font></div>

<div>&#160;</div>

<div align="center"><font style="DISPLAY: inline; FONT-WEIGHT: bold"><font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman">A-39</font></font></div>
</div>

<br>
<hr align="center" noshade size="2" width="100%">
<div id="PGBRK">
<div id="PN" style="PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE: always">&#160;</div>
</div>

<br>
<div style="BORDER-RIGHT: black 1pt solid; PADDING-RIGHT: 20pt; BORDER-TOP: black 1pt solid; PADDING-LEFT: 20pt; PADDING-BOTTOM: 5pt; BORDER-LEFT: black 1pt solid; WIDTH: 100%; PADDING-TOP: 30pt; BORDER-BOTTOM: black 1pt solid">
